litm_code __switch_get_next_subscriber ( litm_connection **  result,
litm_connection *  sender,
litm_connection *  current,
litm_bus  bus_id 
)

Scans the subscription map for the subscriber that follows ``current``. If ``current`` is NULL (thus indicating the start of the scan), then pull the first subscriber from the subscription to bus ``bus_id``.

Furthermore, we are implementing ``split horizon`` forwarding ie. don't send the message back to the originator.

If end of list is reached, return NULL.

CASES: ======

1- empty subscription list 2- single subscriber a) the sender b) other subscriber 3- more than 1 subscriber

00424         int foundNext = 0;
00425         int foundFirst=0, bailOut=0; //FALSE
00426         litm_connection *c=NULL;
00427 
00428         // this shouldn't happen...
00429         if (sender==current) {
00430                 return LITM_CODE_ERROR_SWITCH_SENDER_EQUAL_CURRENT;

00458                                 bailOut=1;
00459                         }
00460 
00461                         // at this point, we are looking for the recipient
00462                         // after ``current`` but that isn't ``sender`` nor NULL
00463                         if (1!=bailOut) {
00464                                 int foundMatch = __switch_find_match(current, bus_id);
00465 
00466                                 if (0==foundMatch) {
00467                                         // can't find ``current``...
00468                                         // maybe the connection was pull-off from our feet
00469                                         returnCode = LITM_CODE_ERROR_SWITCH_NO_CURRENT;
00470                                         bailOut = 1;

00473                                         // need the following subscriber
00474                                         // without forgetting about split-horizon!
00475                                         for ( index=foundMatch+1; index<LITM_CONNECTION_MAX; index++) {

00478                                                         foundNext = index;

void * __switch_thread_function ( void *  params  ) 

The switch thread dequeues messages from the ``input queue`` and dispatches them to the next connection queue.

Definition at line 75 of file switch.c.

00075                                        {
00076 
00077         int pending, action;
00078         litm_code code;
00079         litm_envelope *e;
00080         litm_connection *next, *sender, *current;
00081         litm_bus bus_id;
00082 
00083         DEBUG_LOG(LOG_INFO, "__switch_thread_function: starting");
00084 
00085         //TODO switch shutdown signal check
00086         while(1) {
00087                 // we block here since if we have no messages
00088                 //  to process, we don't have anything else to do...
00089                 e=(litm_envelope *) queue_get_nb( _switch_queue );
00090 
00091                 if (NULL==e) {
00092                         sleep(0.001);
00093                         continue;
00094                 }
00095 
00096                 DEBUG_LOG(LOG_INFO, "__switch_thread_function: GOT ENVELOPE");
00097 
00098                 // The envelope contains the sender's connection ptr
00099                 //  as well as the ``current`` connection ptr.
00100 
00101                 // When the message is first sent on any bus,
00102                 //  the switch sets the ``current`` connection ptr
00103                 //  to the subscriber's connection ptr; this pointer
00104                 //  is obtained by scanning the ``subscription map``
00105                 //  for the first subscriber to the target bus.
00106 
00107                 // BUT FIRST, we need to know if the envelope
00108                 //  was already processed and just waiting to be
00109                 //  sent!
00110 
00111                 // message was processed and just sits pending
00112 
00113                 if (1==e->routes.pending) {
00114                         DEBUG_LOG(LOG_INFO, "__switch_thread_function: ENVELOPE PENDING");
00115 
00116                         current = e->routes.current;
00117                         code = __switch_try_sending_or_requeue( current, e );
00118 
00119                         // if the message was sent or requeued,
00120                         //  we are ok but anything else means something
00121                         //  went wrong (duh!) and since we are the owner
00122                         //  of the envelope/message, we will "recover"
00123                         //  by getting rid of the envelope+message.
00124                         //  REASON:  the probable cause of errors
00125                         //           stems from connection changes
00126                         //           and this is not a normal usage pattern.
00127                         switch(code) {
00128 
00129                         case LITM_CODE_OK:
00130                         case LITM_CODE_BUSY_OUTPUT_QUEUE:
00131                                 break;
00132 
00133                         default:
00134                                 // TODO log error?
00135                                 __switch_finalize(e);
00136                                 break;
00137                         }//switch
00138                         continue;  // <====================================
00139                 }//if
00140 
00141 
00142                 DEBUG_LOG(LOG_INFO, "__switch_thread_function: ENVELOPE NORMAL");
00143 
00144                 // FROM THIS POINT, the envelope was pending
00145                 //  so we need to figured out where to send it next.
00146                 // NOTE: anything short of LITM_CODE_OK gets the
00147                 //       envelope finalized.  This behavior covers
00148                 //       the normal case where all recipients have
00149                 //       had the chance to glance over the message.
00150 
00151                 sender  = e->routes.sender;
00152                 current = e->routes.current;
00153                 bus_id  = e->routes.bus_id;
00154 
00155                 code = __switch_get_next_subscriber(    &next,
00156                                                                                                 sender,
00157                                                                                                 current,
00158                                                                                                 bus_id);
00159 
00160                 if (LITM_CODE_OK!=code) {
00161                         // TODO log error?
00162                         __switch_finalize(e);
00163                         continue; // <=======================================
00164                 }
00165 
00166 
00167                 // WE ARE GOOD TO GO
00168 
00169 
00170                 //adjust envelope
00171                 e->routes.current = next;
00172 
00173                 code = __switch_try_sending_or_requeue( next, e );
00174                 switch(code) {
00175                 case LITM_CODE_OK:
00176                 case LITM_CODE_BUSY_OUTPUT_QUEUE:
00177                         break;
00178 
00179                 default:
00180                         // TODO log error?
00181                         __switch_finalize(e);
00182                         break;
00183                 }
00184 
00185 
00186         }//while
00187 
00188 
00189         return NULL;
00190 }//END THREAD

litm_code __switch_try_sending_or_requeue ( litm_connection *  conn,
litm_envelope *  envlp

)

Try sending the message to the recipient.

This function does not block waiting for the recipient.

litm_code switch_release ( litm_connection *  conn,
litm_envelope *  envlp 
)

A client has finished processing a message: send it through through the ``input_queue`` and if all intended recipients have processed it already, it will be finalized.

Definition at line 200 of file switch.c.

00200                                                             {
00201 
00202         if (NULL==conn) {
00203                 return LITM_CODE_ERROR_BAD_CONNECTION;
00204         }
00205         if (NULL==envlp) {
00206                 return LITM_CODE_ERROR_INVALID_ENVELOPE;
00207         }
00208 
00209         // if a message comes this way, it means a client
00210         // has finished processing it... get rid of the
00211         // "pending" state if at all present.
00212         envlp->routes.pending = 0;
00213 
00214         int result = queue_put(_switch_queue, (void *) envlp);
00215         if (1 != result) {
00216                 __switch_finalize( envlp );
00217                 return LITM_CODE_ERROR_MALLOC;
00218         }
00219 
00220         return LITM_CODE_OK;
00221 }//

Here is the caller graph for this function:

litm_code switch_send ( litm_connection *  conn,
litm_bus  bus_id,
void *  msg,
void(*)(void *msg)  cleaner 
)

This function just queues up the message in the switch's input_queue without actually sending it to recipients.

This function blocks whilst accessing the switch's ``input_queue`` but no deadlock scenario is possible since the switch's thread does not block whilst dequeuing.

Definition at line 334 of file switch.c.

00335                                                     {
00336

00338                 return LITM_CODE_ERROR_BAD_CONNECTION;
00339         }
00340

00342                 return LITM_CODE_ERROR_INVALID_BUS;
00343         }
00344 
00345         // Grab an envelope & init
00346         litm_envelope *e=__litm_pool_get();
00347         e->cleaner = cleaner;
00348         e->routes.pending = 0; //FALSE
00349         e->routes.bus_id = bus_id;
00350         e->routes.sender = conn;
00351         e->routes.current = NULL;  // First time sent
00352         e->msg = msg;
00353 
00354         /*
00355          *  Initial message submission: if something goes
00356          *  wrong, we need to get rid of envelope.
00357          */

00359         if (1 != result) {
00360                 __litm_pool_recycle( e );
00361                 return LITM_CODE_ERROR_MALLOC;
00362         }
00363 
00364         return LITM_CODE_OK;
00365 }//
